text: Aspirin inhibits nuclear factor-kappa B mobilization and monocyte adhesion in stimulated human endothelial cells .

BACKGROUND : The induction of <extra_id_0> vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> E-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is mediated by mobilization of the transcription factor nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) .

text: Since salicylates have been reported to inhibit NF-kappa B activation by preventing the degradation of its inhibitor I kappa B , we studied a potential inhibition of this pathway by acetylsalicylate ( aspirin ) in human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVECs ) .

METHODS AND RESULTS : Gel-shift analyses demonstrated dose - dependent inhibition of <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappa B mobilization by aspirin at concentrations ranging from 1 to 10 mmol / L .

Induction of <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> E-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> surface expression by <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was dose-dependently reduced by aspirin over the same range , while induction of <extra_id_0> intercellular adhesion molecule-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) was hardly affected .

text: As a functional consequence , adhesion of U937 monocytes to <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated HUVECs was markedly reduced by aspirin due to suppression of <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> E-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> upregulation .

text: These effects of aspirin were not related to the inhibition of cyclooxygenase activity , since indomethacin was ineffective .

CONCLUSIONS : Our data suggest that aspirin inhibits NF-kappa B mobilization , induction of <extra_id_0> VCAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> E-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and subsequent monocyte adhesion in endothelial cells stimulated by <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , thereby providing an additional mechanism for therapeutic effects of aspirin .
